item.label: (a)
item.para: United Slates of America.
A. The following is an outline of arrangements Australia is making to help build up educational facilities in some of the above countries:

item.label: (i)
item.para: Malaysia -

subdebate.1.para: Equipment to Schools -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Under technical assistance schemes 6 woodworking schools in Sarawak have recently been equipped.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Equipment will be supplied during 1972-73 to the SANZAC School (Sabah, Australian and New Zealand Army Corp Memorial Medical School, Sabah).

item.label: (li)
item.para: Thailand-

item.label: (a)
item.para: Military Technical Training School -

subdebate.1.para: Australia has provided instructors and equipment to the school since 1958. Between 1967 and 1972, Australia contributed to the cost of the construction of a Motor Mechanics Training wing and provided' instructors. workshop' equipment and vehicles at a total cost of approximately $A900,000. A similar programme is planned for an Electrical Wing between 1972 and 1978.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Asian Institute of Technology -

subdebate.1.para: Australia is financing the building of an administrative block at the Institute at a cost of $500,000. In the past it has provided a Professor of Coastal Engineering to the Institute and currently has a member on the Board of Trustees.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Department of Economic and Technical Co-operation Language Institute

subdebate.1.para: An Australian lecturer in English is currently working at the Department.

item.label: (d)
item.para: Others

subdebate.1.para: In the past, assistance has also been given through the provision of experts to the North Bangkok Engineering School, equipment to the Faculty of Tropical Medicine, University of Medical Sciences and a transmitter to the Bangkok Technical Institute, for educational broadcasting.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: Singapore-

item.label: (a)
item.para: Jurong Vocational Institute -

subdebate.1.para: Since 1966, Australia has provided technical instruction and equipment to the Institute.

item.label: (b)
item.para: University of Singapore -

subdebate.1.para: Australia has and is continuing to provide examiners and lecturers for medical degree examinations.

item.label: (iv)
item.para: Idonesia -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Ministry of Education and Culture - An Australian adviser has been appointed for 1-2 years, to advise and assist the Ministry, in particular on the design of a suitable occupational/apprenticeship training programme, and the planning of short and long term training programmes for technical teachers and administrators.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Jogjakarta Vocational Training Institute

subdebate.1.para: Equipment, and expert services to assist in its installation and to train teachers in its operation, and to advise on a suitable curriculum, will be provided to the Institute during the 1972-73 financial year.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Department of Manpower -

subdebate.1.para: A teacher has been sent to conduct an intensive English language course principally for members of the legal bureau of the Institute.

item.label: (d)
item.para: International Telecommunications Union Training School at Bandung -

subdebate.1.para: Australia is supplying equipment to help equip the telephone exchange unit at the school.

item.label: (v)
item.para: Korea-

subdebate.1.para: Yongsan Technical School -

From 1964 until 1969, a total of $395,000 was spent on equipment and electrical trades instructors for the school. It is intended that a further $111,000 of equipment will be provided during the 1972-73 financial year.

item.label: (vi)
item.para: Philippines -

subdebate.1.para: Bataan National School of Arts and Trades-
A quantity of mechanical equipment is being supplied to the school at present.

item.label: (vii)
item.para: Laos -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Vientiane Teachers Training College -

subdebate.1.para: Three Australian teachers lecture at the College in English and Social Sciences.

item.label: (b)
item.para: School Supplies -

subdebate.1.para: Australia has provided a substantial portion of the school supplies usedin. Lao primary schools. This programme has been in operation since 1962 and items in the sixth consignment will be delivered between 1972 and 1974.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Dong Dok Forestry School -

subdebate.1.para: This school, which is currently being constructed by Australia, will train Laotian forestry rangers. The school is being made of prefabricated Australian buildings and is staffed by two Australian lecturers and Laotian support staff. It is run in co-operation with a LaoAustralian reafforestation project.

item.label: (viii)
item.para: Vietnam -

subdebate.1.para: Bien Hoa Hospital -
The Australian Surgical Team at the hospital has, since 1969, assisted with the training of nurses at the nurses school attached to the hospital.

item.label: (ix)
item.para: Fiji-

item.label: (a)
item.para: University of the South Pacific -

subdebate.1.para: Australia will continue to assist the University of the South Pacific through provision of lectureship subventions and some equipment in the 1972-73 financial year.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Derrick Institute -

subdebate.1.para: The Head of School for business studies at the Institute and a lecturer are provided under the Commonwealth Co-operation in Education Scheme.

item.label: B.
item.para: In addition, arrangements have been made to build up educational facilities in the above countries by:

item.label: (i)
item.para: The provision of Third Country Training Awards for training at the Regional English Language Centre (Singapore), the Civil Aviation Training Centre and the Asian Institute of Technology (Thailand), and the University of the South Pacific (Fiji).

item.label: (ii)
item.para: Support for research projects at the Universities in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia under the Australian/ Asian Universities Co-operation Scheme, and exchanges of staff members under the Scheme.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: Bringing to Australia leading educationists, under the Colombo Plan Special Visitors Scheme and the Commonwealth Cooperation in Education Scheme, to study and discuss Australian methods and techniques.

item.label: (iv)
item.para: A number of the sponsored students from these countries now in Australia are studying subjects relevant to the development of educational facilities in their own countries and will be expected to contribute to this when they have returned home.

item.label: (v)
item.para: There is an educational element in practically all Australian aid projects since the Australian experts concerned are engaged in passing on their own skills to local counterpart staff. Some specific projects (e.g. sheep husbandry in India) involve the organisation and operation of on-the-job training courses.

item.label: (vi)
item.para: The Government provides a subsidy each year to Australian Volunteers abroad. Some 62 teachers, including instructors at teachers colleges, are currently working overseas under the Scheme.

item.label: (vii)
item.para: In addition to aid to educational institutions, Australia currently provides assistance to research institutions in a number of countries, including Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and Burma.

subdebateinfo.title: Telecommunications Conference: Representation of the People's Republic of China (Question No. 5972)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice:

quote.para: Was the People's Republic of China represented at the meeting of a committee of governmental experts held from 9th to 17th May 1972 on problems raised by transmission of broadcasts via space satellites. (Hansard, 17th May 1972, page 2745 and 25th May 1972, page 3198).

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The People's Republic of China was not represented at the meeting of the committee of governmental experts held from 9th to 17th May 1972 in Paris and sponsored jointly by UNESCO and the World Intellectual Property Organisation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Housing, upon notice:

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to the report of the Queensland Government on cyclone Althea.
If so, does the report recommend amendment of building by-laws to meet the. safety requirements of dwellings in cyclone-prone areas.
Will he ensure that war service homes in cyclone areas are built to standards in no way inferior to those recommended by the Queensland report.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: My attention has been drawn to a report prepared for the Queensland Government by members of the James Cook University of North Queensland on the effects of cyclone Althea.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The recommendations contained in the report cover a variety of matters, including necessary amendments to building by.-laws.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The report is very comprehensive and is now being studied by officers of my Department. Full consideration will be given to the recommendations contained in the report in the design and construction of War Service homes in cycloneprone areas.
